## tidytext Package

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[tidytext]

*text here about tidytext package -- explain key vocab like "token"*


]

.panel[.panel-name[`unnest_tokens()`]

**Transforming text into tidy text:** we must break text into individual tokens. That is, each word must have its own line.

- The first argument you must specify is the new column name the text will be unnested into.

- The second argument is the input column the text comes from.

```{r}
text <- c("Because I could not stop for Death -",
          "He kindly stopped for me -",
          "The Carriage held but just Ourselves -",
          "and Immortality")

library(dplyr)
text_df <- tibble(line = 1:4, text = text)
```

```{r}
text_df_unnest <- text_df %>%
  unnest_tokens(word, text)
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[`anti_join()`]

**Removing Stop Words:** `anti_join()` works to remove observations from a specified dataset. Here we will use the `stop_words` dataset from the tidytext package.

- Stop words are words that are not useful for text analysis (e.g., the, a, and, etc.)

```{r}
text_df_unnest %>% 
    anti_join(stop_words)
```

]
